race.name: Ned Gravel
race.tagline: Colorado high country gravel from Nederland. Altitude included.

vitals.aid_stations: Multiple aid stations with full support

climate.description: Late August at 8,000-11,000 feet means cool mornings, warm midday, and afternoon storm risk

terrain.primary: Colorado Front Range gravel with sustained climbing
terrain.surface: Maintained gravel roads, some chunky sections, forest service quality

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Small adjustments for local community vibe. Course -1, editorial +1, overall +5.

history.origin_story: Named for Nederland, Colorado (nicknamed 'Ned' by locals), this race showcases the gravel roads above Boulder's backyard. The Tungsten course pays homage to the Peak to Peak area's mining history, taking riders through ghost towns, past mines, and up mountains on the premier 70-mile route. Created by local organizers who love this quirky mountain town, the race has grown from a local favorite to a respected Colorado gravel event that attracts riders seeking altitude racing without the intensity of Leadville.
notable_moments: 2019: Inaugural race positioned as intimate Colorado high-country experience
2020-2021: Benefits from Nederland's quirky mountain town culture, grows organically
2022-2023: Growing reputation for quality organization and challenging Tungsten course
2024-2025: Established as premier altitude gravel race in Front Range, attracts 400+ riders
history.reputation: A local's favorite that's gaining broader attention. Colorado gravel without the big-race chaos.

course_description.character: The Tungsten course pays homage to the Peak to Peak area's mining history. Riders pass through ghost towns, past mines, and up mountains on the premier 70-mile route. Less technical but more race-oriented, with steep hills and rough country roads.

suffering_zones.label: Ridge Road Climb
suffering_zones.desc: Early sustained climbing on Ridge Road. The altitude starts making itself known as you leave Nederland. Legs fresh but lungs working harder than expected.

suffering_zones.label: Cold Springs Road
suffering_zones.desc: Cold Springs Road delivers more climbing. You're deep in the mountains now, passing ghost towns and old mining sites. The Switzerland Trail section ahead is legendary.
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: Rough country roads with mining history

suffering_zones.label: Switzerland Trail High Point
suffering_zones.desc: The Switzerland Trail reaches its high point above 10,300 feet. Thin air, big views, hard pedaling. This is where the altitude really bites. The descent back to Nederland is fast but requires focus.

suffering_zones.label: Final Push to Nederland
suffering_zones.desc: The final 10 miles back to Nederland. Fast gravel descents and rolling terrain. You're almost home, but the altitude fatigue is real. Stay focused on the technical sections.

course_description.signature_challenge: The Tungsten course combines 8,300 feet of climbing with racing at 8,000-10,300 feet elevation. The altitude compounds the climbing difficulty—your power is compromised, and pacing matters more than raw fitness. The steep hills and rough country roads demand both physical and mental resilience.

prestige.explanation: Not a bucket-list race nationally, but respected in Colorado gravel circles. The Nederland mountain town culture gives it authentic Colorado cred.

length.explanation: The Tungsten course at 70 miles is the premier distance. Less technical but more race-oriented, featuring steep hills and rough country roads. A full day effort at altitude that rewards fitness and pacing.

technicality.explanation: Quality Colorado gravel—not overly technical but varied. Good bike handling helps on descents.

elevation.explanation: 8,300 feet in 70 miles is serious vertical. The Tungsten course includes sustained climbs on Ridge Road, Cold Springs Road, and the Switzerland Trail. Steep hills and rough country roads demand fitness and pacing.

climate.explanation: Late August in Colorado is generally great. Morning chill, afternoon warmth. Thunderstorm risk exists but timing usually favors morning finish.

altitude.explanation: Racing at 8,000-11,000 feet matters. Sea-level riders need 2-4 days minimum acclimation. Altitude is a real factor here.

adventure.explanation: The Colorado Front Range above Boulder is stunning. Nederland itself is a quirky mountain town worth exploring.

biased_opinion.summary: Ned Gravel is the intimate Colorado experience—no massive crowds, no lottery drama, just quality gravel in beautiful high country. The Tungsten course at 70 miles is the premier distance, featuring 8,300 feet of climbing at 8,000-10,300 feet elevation. This is less technical but more race-oriented than other courses, with steep hills and rough country roads that pay homage to the Peak to Peak area's mining history. Perfect for Colorado locals or those who want altitude racing without Leadville's intensity.
strengths: Intimate vibe: Small enough to feel personal, big enough to have energy.
Altitude: Real high-country racing for those who want to test themselves.
Nederland: Quirky mountain town with character.
weaknesses: Size: Less energy than bigger events. If you want festival atmosphere, look elsewhere.
Altitude: Non-acclimated riders will struggle. This isn't optional.
Access: Nederland is close to Boulder but requires mountain driving.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A perfect 'local's race' that visitors can enjoy. Great for altitude testing, Colorado exploration, or just a quality gravel day.

black_pill.title: THE THING NOBODY TELLS YOU
black_pill.reality: Ned Gravel is low-key in the best way. Don't expect Unbound production value. Expect a well-organized race with a small-town vibe. That's the point. But don't let the intimate vibe fool you—the Tungsten course at 70 miles with 8,300 feet of climbing at altitude is a serious challenge. The altitude will affect you more than you think, especially if you're coming from sea level. The steep hills and rough country roads demand fitness and pacing, not just enthusiasm.
consequences: Nederland lodging is very limited. Book immediately or stay in Boulder (30 min drive).
The altitude will affect you. Arrive 2+ days early if coming from sea level.
This is a 'one nice dinner' kind of town. Pack snacks.
black_pill.expectation_reset: This is a solid regional race, not a destination event. The experience is quality—just calibrate expectations for scale.

final_verdict.one_liner: The Tungsten course: 70 miles and 8,300 feet of climbing at 8,000-10,300 feet elevation through Colorado's mining history.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes if you want altitude racing without Leadville's commitment, or want a quality Colorado gravel experience. Great for Front Range locals.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want more challenge: Leadville or Crusher. If you want bigger vibes: SBT GRVL. If you want similar intimacy elsewhere: any regional favorite.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Book immediately. Nederland has few options. Boulder is 30 minutes and has plenty of hotels.
logistics.food: Nederland has a few restaurants. Plan meals or bring supplies.
logistics.packet_pickup: Friday or Saturday morning in Nederland.
logistics.parking: Small-town parking. Arrive early for start area spots.
